Editor by Prof. I.K. Song Styrene is a widely used monomer in polymer industries for the manufacturing of plastics, rubbers and resins. The commercial styrene production process suffers from disadvantages such as requiring multiple steps, catalyst deactivation, high energy consumption and low yield. To address the aforementioned problems, metal complex catalysed single-step oxidative coupling of benzene and ethylene to styrene have been proposed. The attempts so far for the heterogenization of metal complexes lead to worsening the catalytic performance due to metal leaching or clustering. Here, we have presented a first step towards the development of a heterogeneous catalyst to synthesize styrene directly from benzene and ethylene in a single- step. We have anchored palladium nanoparticles on the thermal defect rich surface of graphitic carbon nitride and prepared a heterogeneous catalyst (Pd@d-C3N4) that is active for the single-step styrene production. The product and side-products were analysed by gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry. To understand the role of active sites, the catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy techniques. A combination of microscopic and spectroscopic characterization supports the hypothesis that the activity of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst is associated with their layered structure, surface defect site, and well-stabilized palladium nanoparticles. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Styrene Alkylation Monomer Sustainable process Catalysis Introduction Styrene is an industrially important monomer produced annually on a scale of 20 million tons with a market value of approximately $43.1 billion [1]. The majority of styrene is used in the production of plastics, elastomers, and fine chemicals [2]. Commercially styrene is produced by the alkylation of benzene and ethylene to ethylbenzene followed by dehydrogenation of ethylbenzene to styrene using large feeding streams over the iron oxide-based catalyst [3,4]. This process is extremely endothermic in nature and suffers from thermodynamic limitations. In addition, low atom economy, short catalyst lifetimes and the net emission of greenhouse gases are other drawbacks, associated with this industrial process [5]. In this context, the direct production of styrene from benzene in a one-pot process under moderate reaction conditions is highly desirable [6]. The oxidative coupling of ethylene with benzene is considered a promising alternative process for the production of styrene. This process is mainly conducted in a batch reactor over homogeneous catalysts and styrene is produced by the C-H bond activation of benzene [7,8]. Using direct oxidative conversion of benzene and ethylene, high styrene yield, above 95 mol% styrene yield was claimed at 180°C by Jia et al. The author's proposed a palladium acetate catalyst with the in situ air-recyclable oxidant copper(II) pivalate [9]. The selectivity of styrene can be further enhanced by the addition of ligands such as pyridine or heteropolyacids with palladium acetate catalyst [10,11]. Rh-mediated arylation has also attracted the attention of researchers. Matsumoto and Yoshida have reported significant work on the oxidative arylation of ethylene with benzene to produce styrene by Rh (I) complexes [12,13]. In one such work, the author reveals that Rh(ppy)2(OAc) complex provide better selectivity to styrene (77 mol%) compared to Pd(II) acetate (47 mol%) without the addition of oxidizing agents such as Cu or Ag salts under aerobic conditions [12]. In 2015, Gunnoe et al. pioneered the field of styrene production by introducing rhodium catalysts (FlDAB)Rh(TFA)(h2-C2H4)[14]. The developed metal complex converts benzene and ethylene to styrene with 100 mol% selectivity and ≥95 mol% yields. In this process Cu(II) acetate was utilized as an oxidant similar to the commercialized Wacker-Hoechst process for ethylene oxidation [15]. Cu(II) oxidant can be easily regenerated in the presence of air. However, in this process regeneration was not demonstrated because Rh catalysts can only maintain catalytic activity under an inert atmosphere [16]. To overcome this difficulty, the research group has developed an air-stable (5-FP)Rh(TFA)(η2-C2H4) complex and achieved 91 mol% styrene yield under milder reaction conditions compared to the previous study [17]. The literature review demonstrated that to date only metal complex-based homogenous catalysts have been developed for single-step styrene synthesis. Although their catalytic activities are excellent, the development of low-cost, non-toxic and environmentally benign heterogeneous catalysts is essential to avoid the limitations of a homogenous catalytic system [18]. Graphitic carbon nitride, g-C3N4, is an interesting nitrogen anchored carbon material widely used as a catalyst and catalyst support for photocatalysis, oxidation, hydrogenation, cycloaddition, and esterification reactions [19,20]. The unique two-dimensional layered structure of g-C3N4 is flexible, and consists of defective tri-s-triazine units in which the carbon and nitrogen atoms are in stable conjugating sp2 configuration. The presence of an excess amount of nitrogen and strong covalent bonds between nitrogen and carbon atoms provides this allotrope thermal and chemical stability. The surface modification of the parent graphitic framework by the introduction of many organic and inorganic compounds or metals could improve the reactivity of g-C3N4 and provide novel material for the development of new chemistry [21,22]. The formation of thermal defects in the g-C3N4 framework is an effective way to significantly enhance its catalytic activity [23]. It was demonstrated that the thermal defects can modify the electronic structure and also act as the reactive sites in the reaction system [24]. In addition, the existence of such defects serves as an ideal surface for the adsorption and activation of the reactants because of their abundant localized electrons and interfacial electron transfer mechanism [25]. The thermal defects enhance the content of NH/-NH2 groups on the surface of g-C3N4 [26]. The nitrogen-rich surface provides abundant homogenously distributed anchoring centers that lead to stabilize the anchored metal nanoparticles when g-C3N4 is used as a support in heterogeneous catalysis [27]. More importantly, the strong coordination between the metal nanoparticles and g-C3N4 support induced the electron transfer from NH/-NH2 groups to metal. This electron transfer mechanism makes the metal nanoparticles more electron-rich and consequently makes the metal-g-C3N4 system more reactive [28]. The high temperature calcination is an interesting process to incorporate thermal defects in the g-C3N4 structure. This process avoids the use of surfactant and templating agents and defects can be easily engineered by tuning the processing temperature [29]. In the present study, we have employed this method to obtain high yield d-C3N4 support, decorated with thermal defects. Using this material, we were able to strongly anchor palladium nanoparticles into host cavities, designing the first heterogeneous catalyst for the single-step production of styrene by the oxidative coupling of benzene and ethylene to styrene. This work highlights an important step toward the application of heterogeneous catalyst for styrene production and expands the scope of inexpensive carbocatalysis. Experimental Chemicals The source and purity of the chemicals used are benzene (99.8%, Honeywell), ethylene (99.9%, Messer), copper (II) acetate (98%, Merck), melamine (99%, Sigma Aldrich), palladium (II) acetate (98%, Sigma Aldrich), manganese(II) nitrate tetrahydrate (99%, Sigma Aldrich), cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (98%, Sigma Aldrich), Aluminum nitrate nonahydrate (98%, Sigma Aldrich) and ammonium hydroxide (99%, Honeywell). All the reagents were used as received from commercial suppliers without further purification. Catalysts synthesis Synthesis of g-C3N4 and d-C3N4 supports Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) was prepared by loading 10 g melamine in a muffle furnace and heated to 500 °C (g-C3N4-500), 550 °C (g-C3N4-550) and 600 °C (g-C3N4-600), respectively for 4 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the obtained powder was washed in succession with hydrochloric acid (1 mol L–1) and ultrapure water to remove any alkaline species (e.g., ammonia) adsorbed on the surface of the supports. The washed g-C3N4 was collected by centrifugation and dried at 80 °C for 12 h. To remove the salts that possibly formed during the washing; the catalyst was post-purified by heating at 400 °C for 3 h. The d-C3N4 support was prepared from the same method by calcining the melamine at 640 °C. Synthesis of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst was synthesized by the incipient-wetness impregnation method. Typically, 1 g of d-C3N4 support was added to 20 mL aqueous solution of palladium nitrate under stirring for 20 min. Subsequently, in order to adjust the pH up to 9, an appropriate amount of ammonium hydroxide (0.2 M) was added dropwise under vigorous stirring. The mixture was then stirred for 1 h at 60°C. After cooling to room temperature, the solid was recovered by filtration and washed with ultrapure water and dried in an oven at 60°C for 12 h. The reduction of the sample was performed in a tubular furnace. The sample was initially heated to 200°C in He, followed by heating at the same temperature in 10 vol.% H2 in He (100 mL min–1 total flow) for 2 h. The Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst was subsequently cooled to room temperature under flowing helium. Similarly, Pd-g-C3N4-500, Pd-g-C3N4-550 and Pd-g-C3N4-600 catalysts were also prepared by this method. Graphene oxide, reduced graphene oxide, Mn-rGO, Mn/Ce-rGO, Pd/C, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd-rGO catalysts were prepared by adopting the reported methods [30]. Catalysts characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on PW3040/60 X'Pert PRO MPD diffractometer which was operated at 45 kV and 40 mA with CuKα radiation source (λ=0.154056 nm) at room temperature by a step size of 0.05° in 2θ range from 5° to 90°. Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) database was used for the identification of the phases present in the XRD patterns of the catalysts. Average crystallite sizes of the supports and catalysts were calculated by applying the Debye-Scherrer equation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were carried out by the PHI XPS spectrometer (Physical Electronics). Sample was deposited on adhesive carbon tape and introduced into an ultra-high vacuum spectrometer. The vacuum during XPS analyses was in the range of 10–9 mbar, as a high surface sensitivity is a general characteristic of the XPS methods. Sample surfaces were excited by the X-ray radiation from the monochromatic Al source at the photon energy of 1486.6 eV. High-energy resolution spectra were acquired with the energy analyser, operating at the resolution of about 0.6 eV and the pass energy of 29 eV. During data processing, surface spectra were aligned by setting the C 1s peak at 285.0 eV, the latter being characteristic for C–C bonds. The accuracy of binding energies was about (±0.3 eV. XPS spectra were analysed by the MultiPak software, version 9.9. (Physical Electronics). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements were performed by using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 MP/C apparatus. The measurements were conducted at –196°C temperature. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were calculated from the amount of N2 adsorbed at a relative pressure P/P0 using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation. Prior to characterization, the samples were degassed under N2 flow for 4 h at 200 °C. The pore width was estimated using Barret–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were recorded on Spectrum Two UATR FT-IR spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, USA) at the wavenumbers ranging from 4000 cm−1 to 400 cm−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and EDS-mapping were recorded on JEOL JEM-3010 instrument operated at 300 kV, equipped with a LaB6 filament coupled with energy-dispersive X-ray probe. The atomic force microscopy (AFM) analyses were conducted on a WiTec Alpha300 instrument operating in tapping mode. Three different spots of each sample were selected for the determination of the root-mean-square (RMS) roughness. The ninhydrin test was performed to identify the surface concentration of amine functional groups. [31] Ninhydrin reagent (2,2-dihydroxy-1,3-indanedione) reacts with the primary amino groups of the samples to form a purple-coloured ninhydrin-amino complex called ‘Ruhemann's purple’ (Scheme S1). In this test 1 mL of solution of ninhydrin acetone solution (80 mg mL–1) was added to 2 mL suspension of sample (2.0 mg). The solution was heating in an oil bath at 70 °C for 15 min. The absorption spectra of the heated samples were measured on the Perkin Elmer Lambda 950 UV/VIS/NIR spectrophotometer. Catalytic activity measurement The activity measurements were carried out in a batch autoclave reactor system which consisted of 6 parallel independent batch reactors (system of 6 parallel batch reactors, each of 50 mL, Parr Model 5000) equipped with a magnetic stirring bar, a thermocouple, a pressure gauge, a rupture disk, gas and liquid sampling lines. In a typical experiment, Cu(OAc)2 (1 g) oxidant was dissolved in 10 mL of benzene. The solution was loaded into the reactor with a catalyst (500 mg) and sealed. The reactor was pressurized with N2 to 10 bar and vented three times to remove any residual oxygen atmosphere. Finally, the reactor was pressurized to 15 bar above ambient pressure with ethylene, stirred magnetically (600 rpm) and heated-up to 200 °C. The internal pressure reached 25 bar in the heating-up time of 35 minutes. The recorded reaction time started when the temperature reached the desired set value. Once the reaction was completed the reactor was cool-down to room temperature (20 °C). Final liquid solution (product) was analyzed by gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry (GCMS–QP 2010 Ultra, Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) equipped with a nonpolar column (Zebron ZB–5MS, length 60m, diameter 0.25 mm, film thickness 0.25 μm). Compounds were identified by MS (mass spectrometry; fragments were scanned in the range from 35 to 600 m/z and compared to the NIST 17 (National Institute of Standards and Technology) library) and quantified by FID (flame ionization detector). Analysis method followed the temperature programmed method, initially kept at 323 K for 5.5 min, then increased to 563 K with a heating rate of 20 K min–1, where the temperature was kept constant for an additional 12.5 min. Injection volume was 1.0 μL and the split ratio was set to 30. The injector temperature was maintained at 563 K and FID detector temperature at 573 K. The 5-point calibration curves of reactant and product were prepared in order to obtain reactant conversion and product yield. Results and discussion We have synthesized four g-C3N4 samples by changing the calcination temperatures (500°C to 640 °C) and were used as a support to impregnate palladium nanoparticles. The loading amount of palladium nanoparticles was 3.0 wt% unless otherwise stated. The final materials were denoted as Pd-g-C3N4-500, Pd-g-C3N4-550, Pd-g-C3N4-600 and Pd@d-C3N4. The detailed experimental section is available in the supporting information. In the XRD patterns of bulk g-C3N4 samples the low angle peak at 2θ = 13.5° was assigned to the in-plane structural packing of tri-s-triazine and high angle peak appeared at 2θ = 28.5° corresponds to the inter-planar graphitic stacking of the conjugated aromatic system (Fig. 1 ) [32]. However, in the case of d-C3N4 sample the high angle peak shift to 27.7°, indicates that the high-temperature calcination (640 °C) of carbon nitride leads to an increase the interplanar space [33]. After loading with palladium nanoparticles this peak remains unchanged, confirming that the graphitic interlayer remains constant and the original crystal structure of d-C3N4 support is largely retained. The calculated interlayer distances of graphitic carbon nitrides are similar to those of supported palladium nanoparticles samples (Table S1). According to the literature, the interlayer distance changes when noble metals are present on the surface of the graphitic sheets and remain constant when metals are located within the six-fold cavities [34]. In addition, five well-resolved diffraction peaks in the Pd@d-C3N4 sample are attributed to palladium nanoparticles. The average crystallite size of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst ranges between 14 and 17 nm. In order to identify the electronic state of palladium, surface defects and surface chemical composition, we have performed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements. The elemental survey spectra of the Pd@d-C3N4 shows peaks at 284.70 eV, 336.19 eV and 398.74 eV, due to the presence of carbon (C) palladium (Pd) and nitrogen (N) (Fig. 2 a). The XPS spectra of C 1s for Pd@d-C3N4 can be deconvoluted to four peaks (Fig. 2b). The peak at 286.0 eV is assigned to disordered carbons of both sp3-like configuration and a defective graphitic carbon surface, whereas the other peak at 284.8 corresponds to graphitic carbon, which is typically observed during the XPS analysis of carbon nitride [35]. The major C 1s peak at 288.1 eV ascribed to sp2-bonded C (N-C-N) [36]. Three distinguished peaks appeared in the high-resolution N 1s spectrum of Pd@d-C3N4 (Fig. 2c). The peaks centered at 398.7 eV and 400.0 eV were attributed to sp2-hybridized nitrogen in triazine rings (C-N-C) and the tertiary nitrogen N-(C)3, respectively. The small peak at 404.4 eV is due to the terminal nitrate groups with charging effects or positive charge localization in heterocyclic molecules. Interestingly, the C 1s and N 1s spectra of Pd@d-C3N4 shows negligible changes after the anchoring of palladium nanoparticles compared to bare d-C3N4, suggesting that palladium present in the six-fold cavities (Fig. S1) [37]. The high-resolution spectra of the Pd 3d region are depicted in Fig. 2d, exhibit two types of palladium species. The strong 3d5/2 peak at lower binding energy (336.2 eV) and 3d3/2 peak located at higher binding energy (341.4 eV), originate from metallic Pd [38]. Another doublet originated from 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 with relatively low intensity at 338.65 eV and 343.91 are well in agreement with the +2-oxidation state of palladium (Pd2+) species. However, the fraction of Pd2+ phases in the catalyst is favourable for achieving better results in our reaction [39]. XPS analyses were performed on a couple of catalysts among them were a fresh and a recycled catalyst (R-Pd@d-C3N4) in order to see possible differences. The Pd-g-C3N4-550 catalyst showing mediate conversion efficiency of 9.0% and low selectivity 0.7 was analysed by XPS. In addition, the d-C3N4 catalyst was also analysed. Normalize XPS spectra C 1s, N 1s and Pd 3d from these catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 (b–d). As one can see there are no significant differences between them. All of them have features described above for C 1s, N 1s and Pd 3d spectra. To show in more details the Pd 3d spectra we plotted them also on the same intensity scale (Fig. 3d). In these spectra again well resolved Pd 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 doublet at 336.2 eV and 341.5 eV is observed related to metallic Pd0 and Pd2+ on all catalysts. No additional broadening related with new oxidation states of the Pd atoms was observed. Small differences in C 1 s spectra in Fig. 3a among the samples may be noted in a larger relative portion of graphitic carbon at 284.8 eV from g-C3N4 sample with respect to sp2-bonded carbon (C-N-C) at 288 eV. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the supports and catalyst is depicted in Fig. 4 . All samples featured stretching vibration modes of C=N and C–N bonds between 1500–1650 cm–1 and 1250–1490 cm–1, respectively, which are associated with the aromatic tri-s-triazine units [40]. The absorption peak appearing in the range of 810 cm–1 may be attributed to the breathing mode of heptazine units [38]. The peak located at around 3100–3400 cm–1 is ascribed to stretching vibration modes of N–H bonds. It was observed that in the FT-IR spectra of d-C3N4 the intensities of bands at 1210 cm–1, 1240 cm–1 and 1320 cm–1 have increased which would mean that high temperature calcination of melamine generates more –NH/NH2 groups. This indicates that in the structure of d-C3N4 large portions contain only a few heptazine units connected with more C–NH–C bridges. The enhancement of the terminals –NH/NH2 groups in the small polymer segments lead to the formation of thermal defects [41]. It was evidently visible that no obvious change in the FT-IR spectra of Pd@d-C3N4 has occurred after the anchoring of palladium nanoparticles, indicating that the molecular structure of d-C3N4 is rather stable under the strong basic conditions used for the preparation of the catalyst due to the strong van der Waals forces between the single layers [42]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to further observe the morphologies and structures of the Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst in comparison with bulk g-C3N4 and d-C3N4 supports, as displayed in Fig. 5 . Unlike the bulk structure of g-C3N4 (Fig. 5a), the d-C3N4 support exhibited thinner two-dimensional layered morphology (Fig. 5b), which was also observed in a sample of Pd@d-C3N4 (Fig. 5c). This change in surface morphology is in qualitative agreement with that in the specific surface areas of the catalyst and supports. The high-magnification TEM image of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst reveals that palladium nanoparticles with the size of 15–20 nm are distinctly anchored on d-C3N4 nanosheets (Fig. 5d). Fig. 5e, represents a high resolution TEM image of an individual palladium nanoparticle on d-C3N4 surface with a lattice-fringe spacing of 0.25 nm, which is assigned to the (111) plane of Pd [38]. In the selected area diffraction pattern (SAED) clear lattice fringes indicated the polycrystalline nature of the catalyst (Fig. 5f). The observed rings are well indexed with the characteristic planes (002), (111), (200) and (220) of XRD results. Additionally, EDX elemental analysis verifies the presence of C, N, and Pd in the Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst (Fig. 5g-j and Fig. S2). More detailed information about the thickness and morphology was offered by the atomic force microscopy (AFM) in tapping mode. The AFM images further approved the layered structure of d-C3N4 support (Fig. 6 a-b). The surface roughness of the g-C3N4 synthesized at different temperatures was found to increase in the order of g-C3N4-500 > g-C3N4-550 > g-C3N4-600 > d-C3N4 with the root‐mean‐square (RMS) roughness values of 64 nm, 49 nm, 35 nm and 25 nm, respectively (Fig. S3-S6). The change of roughness probably related to the fact that the thermal treatment induced important structural modifications that convert the polymeric materials to more graphitic ones and make the surface smooth [43]. The mesoporous nature of the samples was confirmed by the strong adsorption and H3-type hysteresis loop in N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm curves (Fig. 6c-d, Fig. S7-S8) [44–45]. It was observed that the surface area and pore volume of the catalysts increases with the processing temperature (Table 1 ) suggest that the introduction of thermal defects unfolded the graphitic nanosheets, as confirmed by the HRTEM. The enhancement of the surface area for Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst (52.78 m2 g–1) in comparison to bare d-C3N4 support is due to the fact that the interlayer stacking forces between the graphitic nanosheets were significantly reduced by the presence of palladium nanoparticles that acts as a separator and increase the surface area, as previously reported [46–48]. For all the catalysts, the diameter of the pores is in the ranges of 21–33 nm. To further verify the surface concentration of amine functional groups, we have employed the ninhydrin assay [31]. Ninhydrin reagent (2,2-dihydroxy-1,3-indanedione) reacts with the primary amino groups of the samples to form a purple-coloured ninhydrin-amino complex called ‘Ruhemann's purple’ (Scheme S1). The optical densities of the samples were determined by UV-Vis spectrophotometer, which is proportional to the concentration of amino groups. It became apparent that the intensity of absorption peak (λmax = 570 nm) has increased with the processing temperature, which confirmed that the surface concentration of –NH/NH2 groups in d-C3N4 is temperature dependent (Fig. S9). The result of the element analysis is a convincing proof of the existence of nitrogen defects. It was observed that the mass ratio of N:C for the Pd-g-C3N4-500 catalyst was 1.91 that significantly decreased to 0.97 in case of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst (Table S2). The decrease of nitrogen content indicates the existence of nitrogen vacancies after the thermal treatment [49]. The XPS results further confirmed that the missing N atoms mainly originate from amino groups and some two-coordinated nitrogen. For a better understanding of the interaction between palladium nanoparticles with surface defective sites of d-C3N4, we have speculated the structure of Pd@d-C3N4. In general, g-C3N4 has a Sierpinski sieve‐like lattice structure made from tri-s-triazine units connected by nitrogen atoms. However, the final structure, composition and morphology of g-C3N4 depend upon calcination temperature, precursor and production route. The high temperature calcination of melamine generates more –NH/NH2 groups on the terminating edges of tri-s-triazine rings that change the color of g-C3N4 from light yellow to brown and produce thermal defects in the final material (Fig. S10) [27]. There were a total of eleven adsorption sites including five non-equivalent atom sites of N and C (N1, N2, N3, C1 and C2), four bond sites (B1, B2, B3, and B4) and two interstitial sites (I2 and I3) available in the structure of defect free g-C3N4, where dopant atoms can occupy substitutional or interstitial positions (Scheme 1 a) [50]. The four bond sites were corresponding to the N1–C1, C1–N2, N2–C2 and C2–N3 bonds of triazine rings. One interstitial site was delimited by six C3N4 rings called “six-fold cavity” (I2) and another interstitial site was the centre of the C3N4 ring (I3). Catalytic performance Generally, the oxidative coupling of benzene and ethylene to styrene requires either molecular oxygen or oxidizing agent to reoxidize the transition metal that is reduced in the course of the reaction via reductive elimination[12]. However, we have chosen a stoichiometric amount of air-recyclable copper (II) acetate as the in situ oxidant to regenerate Pd(II) because of the explosive nature of the ethylene and oxygen mixture. The separation of copper(II) acetate is known for the commercialized Wacker–Hoechst process to produce acetaldehyde by the oxidation of ethylene over palladium(II) catalysts [51–53]. In search of an active catalyst for the production of styrene, we have tested different solid materials including CeO2-rGO, Mn-rGO, Mn/Ce-rGO, Pd/C, Pd/Al2O3 and Pd-rGO knows for the effective oxidative coupling reaction. However, no coupling product was detected over these solid catalysts. In order to check the applicability of g-C3N4 in our reaction, we have conducted some preliminary experiments. It was confirmed from the FT-IR and XPS analysis that the concentration of surface defects in polymeric g-C3N4 has increased with the processing temperature, therefore, it is sensible to investigate the influence of the surface defect sites on styrene selectivity over bare and palladium nanoparticles anchored g-C3N4 prepared at four different temperatures. As expected, we have not detected styrene in the reaction mixture when reactions were conducted with bare supports (Table 2 , entries 1-4). Upon anchoring with palladium nanoparticles all the supports became active and exhibited some catalytic activity (Table 2, entries 5–8). These results affirm that the anchoring of transition metal is essential for this transformation as previously reported [14]. We have achieved a maximum 8.9% conversion and 7.4 mol% selectivity over Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst, evident the necessity of defects to catalyse this reaction [54]. Apart from the defects, other structural properties of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst were also responsible for the better activity compared to Pd-g-C3N4 catalysts. In order to improve the selectivity of styrene over the Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst, we have varied reaction time, and temperature. Unfortunately, it did not improve the styrene selectivity (Table 2, entry 9-10). The catalytic efficiency of different Pd-g-C3N4 materials was not desirable due to their small specific surface areas (< 26 m2 g–1) compared to Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst (52.7 m2 g–1), which can limit the target-active site contact surface. Notably, the content of palladium loading also affects the oxidative coupling of benzene and ethylene. The Pd-g-C3N4-500 and Pd-g-C3N4-550 catalysts with excess palladium loading (∼ 2 wt%) are less selective for styrene production. This may be due to the fact that the high metal content blocks the accessible active sites of the catalysts [55]. We strongly believe that styrene selectivity is influenced by multiple factors. Some formation of side products originating from benzene is noticed, such as stilbene, γ Phenylbutyrolactone, 1-Phenyl-1,2-ethanediol diacetate and 4-Phenylbutanol (Scheme 2 ). However, aside from stilbene, all of these represent less than 5% of the area of styrene. The only other product worth mentioning is stilbene which accounts less than 50% of the area of styrene. Due to the colour of the reaction mixture, we also suspect some polymerization to larger compounds occurs (Fig. S11). These have a boiling point higher than the temperature of the liner, and they likely remain in the reactor (are not analysed). Furthermore, there is a lot of acetic acid and its derivatives (such as acetylacetone) present in the reaction mixture. For the latter products, it is impossible to say if they are purely the result of copper acetate decomposition, or if benzene also decomposes. Finally, we have conducted the recycling test to examine the stability of the (R-Pd@d-C3N4) catalyst. After each run, the catalyst was isolated from the reaction mixture through centrifugation and filtration. The obtained solid was thoroughly washed with aqueous ammonia solution until a colourless aqueous layer is obtained. This washing procedure has removed the impurities of copper in the form of blue copper-ammonia complex [56]. The solid was then washed with hydrochloric acid (1 mol L–1) and ultrapure water to remove ammonia adsorbed on the surface and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 6 h. The dried catalyst was used for the next cycle directly under the identical reaction conditions. The results showed that the catalyst was stable, and its activity remained almost constant throughout the recycling experiment (Table 2, entry 11). The Pd@d-C3N4 catalysed reaction closely follows the traditional homogeneous catalysis pathway with just a few differences [14]. In the metal complex catalysed production of styrene electron rich ligands is essential for the activation of benzene. The ligand with multiple coordination sites also helps to suppress irreversible oxidation to inactive metal centers in presence of an oxidant [57]. Although the coordination of ligands is important in the homogeneous system, the deactivation of the catalyst and rapid aggregation of the metal was observed in the reported metal complexes [58]. In addition, the strong metal ligand interaction makes the catalyst less active because the activation of the catalyst requires ligand removal. In the Pd@d-C3N4 catalysed reaction defect abundant N-sites fulfil the function of ligand and provide the necessary electron density required for the activation of benzene. The presence of multiple coordination sites in the fixable lattice enables transfer of charge continuously to palladium during the reaction that enhances the stability of the catalyst. The chemical environment and binding of the metal atom for such materials remain constant during the reaction cycle [59,60]. Conclusion In the quest to achieve a single-step production of styrene by a heterogeneous catalyst that overcomes the limitations of state-of-the-art homogeneous catalysts, we have designed and synthesized palladium nanoparticles anchored on graphitic carbon nitride decorated with thermal defects. Among all the tested catalysts, Pd@d-C3N4 yielded styrene with 7.4 mol% selectivity under moderate reaction conditions. The extensive spectroscopic measurements and structural analysis of the catalyst reveal the pivotal role of the defect rich graphitic carbon nitride, which as an electron abundant host stabilizes palladium nanoparticles, promotes the adsorption and activation of the substrates. The insights gained from this work open up wide technological potential of graphitic carbon nitride for heterogenization of challenging chemical processes. Our findings will inspire the design of cost-effective heterogeneous catalysts for C-C bond coupling of other arenes with olefins that are presently being conducted over metal complexes and update the basic understanding of carbocatalysis. In the present study, we have demonstrated for the first time that heterogeneous catalysts can also be used for the one-pot styrene production. We believe that our findings will motivate the researcher to develop a more active and selective heterogeneous catalyst for styrene production. Further studies are ongoing to improve styrene selectivity by tuning the active sites and optimizing the reaction conditions. The future work should be the focus on replacement of the expensive palladium metal with more earth-abundant metals like nickel, copper or cobalt to make this process industrially viable. coredata.dc:description: Styrene is a widely used monomer in polymer industries for the manufacturing of plastics, rubbers and resins. The commercial styrene production process suffers from disadvantages such as requiring multiple steps, catalyst deactivation, high energy consumption and low yield. To address the aforementioned problems, metal complex catalysed single-step oxidative coupling of benzene and ethylene to styrene have been proposed. The attempts so far for the heterogenization of metal complexes lead to worsening the catalytic performance due to metal leaching or clustering. Here, we have presented a first step towards the development of a heterogeneous catalyst to synthesize styrene directly from benzene and ethylene in a single- step. We have anchored palladium nanoparticles on the thermal defect rich surface of graphitic carbon nitride and prepared a heterogeneous catalyst (Pd@d-C3N4) that is active for the single-step styrene production. The product and side-products were analysed by gas chromatography coupled with mass spectrometry. To understand the role of active sites, the catalysts were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), atomic force microscopy (AFM), Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy techniques. A combination of microscopic and spectroscopic characterization supports the hypothesis that the activity of Pd@d-C3N4 catalyst is associated with their layered structure, surface defect site, and well-stabilized palladium nanoparticles.
coredata.dc:title: Single step production of styrene from benzene by alkenylation over palladium-anchored thermal defect rich graphitic carbon nitride catalyst
